segments.text: So this is clearly a case where international cooperation is highly desirable in a funny sort of way.
That is, it's one facility, the Glomar Challenger, the only ship of its kind in the world.
And it's very expensive to operate.
And yet it can serve the interests
of scientists from many different countries.
Just exactly the opposite of the other justification I gave a few minutes ago, where you need facilities from many different countries to study one phenomenon.
Here you have the possibility of studying many phenomena, which scientists from many different countries are interested in.
But no one country, except the United States, feels that it can afford it.
operate the equipment single-handed.
And we welcome very much the financial participation and the scientific participation of people from other countries.
So in both the justifications I've given, the cooperation is basically in terms of facilities, facilities belonging to different countries or facilities
belonging to one country but used by many different countries.
A third reason for international cooperation is to share results and ideas.
And this is accomplished by various kinds of scientific unions or other organizations for that purpose.
In the case of oceanography, as we said yesterday, oceanography is not really a science.
a lot of different sciences doing research on an object of study, namely the ocean, namely that part of the earth which is covered in seawater.
That is the air and the solid earth and the water itself and the critters that live in the water.
And so there's no international union
a disciplinary union that deals specifically with the ocean.
There are lots of them, the physicists, the chemists, the biologists, the geologists, the geologists, and geophysicists.
They're all interested in ocean science.
So you need an organization which is orthogonal to the disciplinary unions, an object of study union.
And that's furnished by the Scientific Committee on Oceanic Research, SCORE, which consists of representatives of the different unions.
And in each union, there is one or more associations particularly concerned with the ocean, not in every union, but in three or four of them.
For example, in the International Union of Geology and Geophysics, there's the Association of Physical Sciences of the Ocean.
In the Union of Biological Sciences, there's the Association for Marine Biology.
In the Union of Geological Sciences,
a section or commission on marine geology, submarine geology, and so forth.
And all these associations come together under the leadership of SCORE to have a joint oceanographic congress, an international oceanographic congress, every three or four years.
The next one will be in Edinburgh this fall.
There was one in Tokyo.
two or three years ago, and before that one in Moscow.
The first one was the one that you referred to, which was held at the United Nations headquarters in New York, called the First International Oceanographic Congress.
And that was the one that was masterminded by Mary Sears, which I was the president of.
I thought it was a tremendous occasion, and they're all very good occasions, these oceanographic congresses.

They're the only way in which you can bring together people from all the various sciences that are connected with the ocean, that are interested in the ocean, to talk to each other about the ocean and not about their science, not about their particular discipline of science.
And this also leads to another kind of cooperation, which is scientists working in each other's laboratories or on each other's ships.
For example, on our mid-Pacific expedition, Anri Roche, my friend, who's now in New Caledonia, took part in that.
You did set up this Soviet geophysicist I've been telling you about, and several of his associates have been out on our ships.
We've been out on the Russian ships.
And there's often exchange in the laboratory, too, when working out the results.
These are very valuable learning experiences on both sides.
They're mutually beneficial.
I think that
I would say several things about international cooperation.
One is that it's darn difficult.
Therefore, you don't want to do it unless you have to.
It's more difficult on a worldwide basis than it is on a regional basis.
Much easier cooperation between two countries is much easier than cooperation between three, and the difficulties go up exponentially as the number of countries increases.
And the effectiveness goes down.
In some cases, you have to have many countries.
In my experience in oceanography, international cooperation never works unless the Americans take the lead.
And there's several reasons for this.
One reason is we've got so many scientists.
one third of all the science in the world.
The more important reason is that we're used to cooperation.
We're kind of a league of nations.
The United States all by itself is kind of a league of nations in the sense that it's so big and has so many institutions that have to learn how to cooperate with each other.
And we have a tradition of what de Tocqueville called voluntary associations.
Remember, de Tocqueville said that whenever two or more Americans have an objective, something that they want to accomplish, they form a voluntary association for every conceivable purpose.
And we're in France to find the government taking the lead
push different interests or different objectives.
And in England, you'd find some aristocratic leader pushing an objective.
In the United States, you have a voluntary association.
These voluntary associations are ways in which we Americans learn how to get things done together.
So we have a great advantage.
in international scientific cooperation, simply because we've had a lot of experience thinking of ways to cooperate.
In any case, I think the record would show that it works best when the Americans are very much involved.
Now, one of the aspects of being very much involved is that we don't ever get out in front.
I almost never find an American as a president of an association, an international cooperative enterprise.
But you're very often finding a secretary.
And this is part of the technique of doing the job.

For example, the first secretary of the UNESCO Office of Oceanography was an American named Warren Wooster, who at that time was with Scripps, and later became director of the Rosenstiel Marine Laboratories at the University of Miami, and has now just gone to the University of Washington.
He's probably the most talented scientific bureaucrat I've ever seen in my life.
Remember I told him, I mentioned him yesterday, he had a great expedition.
Just very good at getting, at administering big, big scientific enterprise.
Then later he was the secretary and president of SCORE.
And that's what really made SCORE work.
His very great effectiveness is running it.
But another aspect of scientific cooperation is that it just doesn't work if you let politics get involved in it.
And this is what's unfortunately happened to the IOC, the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission.
It's really been taken over by the diplomats.
But its effectiveness is very, very low now.
For the first 10 years, the delegates were scientists.
The scientists had no trouble agreeing, but once you get the politicians into the act, everything slows down to a grinding halt.
I wrote a paper, or I gave a paper about a year ago, which I called Ten Commandments for International Cooperation.
I mean, and I thought I would tell you now some of these commandments.
One other, there are several others, but they're all sort of second to the ones I've just stated.
Like, for example, you really want to do a, you want to prepare for it.
And no meeting really works unless you have a, have it in the right place, with the right people,
carefully prepared agenda and careful attention to everything from housing to food to entertainment to the lack of distraction.
For example, we had a very successful meeting organized by Warren Wooster on the island of Ponza off the Italian coast.
And the reason it was successful was, A, it was a beautiful place, and, B, you couldn't do anything else but talk to the demography for four days, for a week, because there was nothing else there.
Well, those are all sort of experience, details.
Details learned by experience.
So I'm proud of
several things here, but basically I'm proud of the fact that many Americans, many American oceanographers now are enthusiastic about international society cooperation.
Whereas to begin with, that was not the case.
Now, what issues did you advise the Secretary of Interior on from 61 to 63?
What issues?
Why would you be attached to the Secretary of Interior's office in the sense of a special advisor?
Well, that's a good question.
The answer is not very simple.
I was a good friend of Jerry Weasley.
who was President Kennedy's science advisor.
We've gotten to know each other through the Pugwash movement, and also in various other scientific .
So when Kennedy came into office,
Jerry became his special assistant for science and technology.
He felt that every department should have what amounted to an assistant secretary for science and technology.
And there was one already in the Navy, Jim Wakelin, one of these guys.
By the way, the name of that coordinator for research and development was Fuhrer, F-U-H-R-E-R.
He'd been an admiral through his staff and later became assistant secretary of the Navy for science and technology.
And Jerry was able to get an assistant secretaryship established in the Department of Commerce for Holloman.
He took that job.
And in the Army and in the Air Force.
And in the

Some other departments, it was impossible to establish another assistant secretary, but they instead put in this Office of Science Advisory, which was true of HEW, and true of Interior, and true of State, the State Department.
And I guess it was also more or less true
Science advisor, it was a political appointment, but it didn't have to be confirmed by the Senate.
The secretary himself could make it.
Your title was special assistant to the secretary.
Well, Stuart Udall didn't really want a science advisor.
He didn't quite know what to do with one.
But he didn't object.
He thought it might be a good idea.

Well, the Department of the Interior is a collection of baronets or dukedoms, the heads of which are each more powerful than the secretary, including the Geological Survey, the Bureau of Reclamation, the Bureau of Land Management,
at that time Bureau of Commercial Fisheries and Sports Fisheries and Wildlife, the National Park Service, Bureau of Mines, and the various offices.
And particularly the old line agencies like the Geological Survey and the Bureau of Reclamation had developed constituencies in Congress and in the states.
So they had an enormous continuing strength.
I remember very well Floyd Dominey, the Commissioner of Reclamation, the slippery character.
very, really, you know, quite arrogantly powerful for a very good reason.
You have the Congressman eating out of his hand.
It's the undersecretary of a man named, when I was arrogant, it was Carr.
I'm thinking about the one right after Carr.
He was an
Carter, I guess his name was Carter.
He was an idealistic politician who took a really a dim view of dealing with the Bureau of Reclamation.
Political plums and political punishment that they dealt out to congressmen, depending on what they supported them about.
And they severely criticized Dominie one time.
Dominie said, if you don't like what I'm doing, why don't you fire me?
Well, the outshot was that a week later, Carter was out of a job as undersecretary.
He was just, I mean, Dominie was just too powerful.
So there was really very little to do for a science advisor to do in the Office of the Secretary of the Interior.
I did some things.
I had a very good assistant named Howard Echols.
One of the things we did was to get a National Academy study of the National Park Service, which resulted in the firing of the director, which was a

major coup in Stuart's cap, or Petterson's cap, major coup, just for this reason I've been outlining, that these guys all had their contention, including Conrad Worth, the director of the National Park Service.
But it was clear from the National Academy study that the Park Service really was not doing a very good job.
We had another study of
of solar energy.
Again, I got a National Academy committee to look into the possibilities for solar energy.
Hubert Humphrey was pushing very hard for us to establish an office for solar energy.
The trouble was he backed away from getting any congressional authorization or appropriation for it.
He wanted us to do it on our own.
And we had a study being put together
spelled out, more or less, the possibilities for research and development of solar energy.
At that time, they were rather dim.
The reason was the price of oil and coal was so much lower than it is now.
Now the prospects for solar energy are very much better.
But they weren't very good when it was $3 a barrel, or $1 a gallon.
They don't look very good now, but they look an awful lot better.
The other option was nuclear energy.
It worries a lot of people.
The other thing I did was to make a study of the charge of the study of a combination
possibilities of combining nuclear electric power generation with salt water conversion.
In other words, using the low temperature steam for evaporating seawater and high temperature steam for making electric power.
I was chairman of the Federal Council of Science and Technology Committee on
I was a member of the Federal Council for Science and Technology and chairman of their committee on water resources research.

And we actually managed to get an office of water resources research established in the Department of Interior, which in turn supports institutions for water resources research in every state in the country.
partly on a formula basis and partly on a research grant basis.
We have one in Texas.
Every state has one.
This was a very difficult thing to do because every other department, half a dozen departments, are interested in water.
And every department fights like a food tiger for its cognizance and its prerogatives.
And the Agriculture Department and the Commerce Department
and the Department of Defense.
I guess that was all.
None of them thought it was a good idea to give this job to Interior.
They'd rather not have it done at all than have Interior do it, because it looked like it might interfere with their prerogative.
But fortunately, Orville Freeman and Stuart Udall were good friends.
And so the Agriculture Department finally agreed to it.
And this was, the law was passed, and it was done.
That was perhaps the most important long-range thing I did for the Department of the Interior.
I tried to do something about the geological survey in particular.
getting them to support more research in colleges and universities, following along the lines of ONR and NSF, never had any success.
And they in general took a very dim view of the Secretary's office, let alone the science advisors.
There was a guy named Tom Nolan who ran the survey
Geological Survey people always appear at a meeting, a government meeting, and find themselves not Department of the Interior, but U.S. Geological Survey.
They regard themselves as kind of a separate branch of the government.
And that's true in general of these old-line agencies.
My job was to work for Jerry Wiesman.
And this really changed my career.
It changed my whole life.
I think, wait a second now, you better repeat that now for a second, because I think our tape had a 15-second delay.
In the meantime, why don't we go to the bathroom?
Okay.
